snippet: Neil Heywood’s ties to Bo Xilai and his family may have cost him his life and set off China’s biggest political scandal in a generation. But precisely why, or how, he died is still unknown.
abstract: Little is known about British man Neil Heywood and his ties to ousted Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, whose wife Gu Kailai is suspected of murdering Heywood over a business dispute; Heywood's acquaintances, who say he was elusive about his business dealings, cannot explain why, after yearlong estrangement from the Bo family, Heywood turned up in Chongqing, province presided over by Bo, where his body was found in a hotel.

byline.original: By SHARON LaFRANIERE and JOHN F. BURNS
byline.contributor: Sharon LaFraniere reported from Beijing, and John F. Burns from London. Andrew Jacobs contributed reporting from New York, Ravi Somaiya from London, and Didi Kirsten Tatlow from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Neil Heywood’s ties to Bo Xilai and his family may have cost him his life and set off China’s biggest political scandal in a generation. But precisely why, or how, he died is still unknown.
